He woke up to an empty house, the silence heavier than usual. The coffee maker beeped, but it was her favorite mug that caught his eye. Sitting alone in the cupboard, untouched since she passed last month. He reached for it, then hesitated, his hand trembling. "Why did you have to go?" he whispered, despair welling up as he clutched the cold ceramic to his chest.

He poured himself a cup using her mug, despite knowing it would never taste the same without her there, chattering softly about nothing while she waited for hers to cool. He took a sip, scalded his tongue, and cursed under his breath, "Damn it, woman. Even your coffee's better than mine."

He looked at the photo of them on the counter, her smile brighter than any sunrise he'd ever seen. "You always did everything better," he muttered, setting the mug down with a thud. He grabbed his keys and stormed out, leaving the empty house to its heavy silence.

On the drive to work, he passed a couple walking hand in hand, laughing at something only they understood. "Assholes," he muttered, clenching his jaw. "They don't know how good they've got it." He felt the familiar pang of jealousy, followed by shame. Why couldn't he be content with what he had? What was wrong with him?

His colleague, Sarah, greeted him at the office door. "Morning," she said cheerfully. He grunted in response, watching as she effortlessly juggled her coffee and files while he struggled to keep his grip on her mug.

"Morning, sunshine!" Their boss called out from across the room. He forced a smile, but inside, he felt like a failure. Again.

"I swear, if that bloody phone rings one more time..." I muttered under my breath, glaring at the offending device as it vibrated insistently on my desk. The screen illuminated with his name, casting a harsh glow in the dim studio lighting. "Not tonight, James," I whispered, willing him to hang up.

I couldn't shake off the unease that had settled over me like a shroud since he'd first started calling. What if it was important? What if something had happened to one of the kids? Or what if... no, I wouldn't think about that. Not tonight, not with this blank canvas staring back at me, daring me to fail.

My heart pounded in my chest like a war drum, echoing off the stark walls of my studio. Each unanswered ring felt like a challenge, a dare from him—from myself—to face whatever bad news awaited on the other end. But I couldn't. Not now. Not when my hands were already trembling, my mind racing with images of disaster and despair.

"What if...?" I caught myself beginning that dreadful question again, my grip tightening around the paintbrush until my knuckles turned white. "No," I hissed aloud, slamming the brush down onto the palette with a force that sent specks of dried paint flying. "I won't. Not tonight."

I watched the phone as it fell silent, his calls unanswered, my fears left unacknowledged. The clock ticked on, each passing second a reminder of the what-ifs I refused to entertain, at least for now. But they were there, lurking in the shadows of my mind, waiting like vultures for the moment my guard was down.

"Tomorrow," I promised myself, turning back to the canvas with renewed determination. "Tomorrow, I'll face whatever it is he wants. Tonight... tonight, I paint."
